story:
Let's Save Our Aging .....

Moderate Living for the Aging (M.L.F.T.A.) is a Non-Profit 501(c)3 organization for the aging, helping our elderly age successfully and with dignity.   This agency does this by providing advocates to help educate the elderly .   Our organization originated in 1997 as we began to experience the aging of our own parents.   We began to recognize the lack of services available to enable the elderly the resources necessary to age with the dignity they are so deserving of.
 
Too often the elderly in our society are cast aside, even though they still have so much to offer.  Many of their basic necessities of life are not always being met.   M.F.L.T.A attempts to provide safe living conditions, assistance with supplemental food deliveries, utilities, and prescriptions.

M.L.F.T.A has also been active in joining forces with a national construction company to assist  with the necessary repairs caused by storm damage.  We are currently working to procure pre-paid gas cards to enable transportation to and from doctor's appointments, grocery / pharmacy shopping, and other productive activities.  Keenager care is yet another project we are passionate about.  This service will help provide seniors with a little bit of extra care they are in need of during the day while their employed caregivers are away at work.  We will be offering this program to provide the seniors with activities during the day,  breakfast, lunch, and even something as simple as a phone call saying a friendly hello.

With the holiday season upon us, we are looking forward to being able to continue to provide our services and by offering even more for our elderly this year. Unfortunately, this is the time of the year many seniors are often over looked when it comes to their prescription medicine, transportation, and adequate housing needs. Speaking of the Holiday Season.  Have you ever had the opportunity to watch when one of our elderly receives a gift on Christmas?   They are happier and even more excited  than a child, especially when they thought everyone had forgotten about them.

M.L.F.T.A is a national organization and is able to be utilized by anyone, everywhere.  We are the ones reaching out to help provide the elderly with their necessities.  We do all of the leg work by providing the right resources in capable hands to fulfill these needs.

Please help us continue these fine works for such a great cause.  Even the smallest of donations would enable us to continue to provide these much needed services, by allowing the elderly to have the comfort in knowing  there is a place they can turn to and not be left out in the cold!


Visit our website, www.mlfta.org

And PLEASE help spread the word! Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
A small mechanical device embedded in an athlete’s helmet or headband which measures, alerts and archives the impact sustained.


PROBLEM

Concussions in sports have hit center stage as of late with the growing research on brain disease both at the professional and youth level.  The CDC estimates that 1.6 to 3.8 million concussions occur each year affecting 5-10% of athletes, which is why every major news publication has been covering this issue.  

As more is being learned about sport’s impacts and the effects of concussions on long term brain health, medical professionals are looking more into the history of concussions and the cumulative effect of those incidents. (source: http://www.concussiontreatment.com/concussionfacts.html#sfaq9)


SOLUTION

MEASURE

A miniature sensor fits into a helmet or headband and wirelessly broadcasts data to our secure servers within seconds using Wi-Fi or personal hotspot. If these are not available, the data can be synced up once the device is back within Wi-Fi range.

Impact:

Measures impacts of 1g to 250g via 3 axis accelerometer. G: a unit of force equal to the force exerted by gravity; used to indicate the force to which a body is subjected when it is accelerated. (source: http://wordnetweb.princeton.edu/perl/webwn?s=g-force)

Direction: 

Determines direction of the impact a player sustains in six different directions.

Temperature:

Monitors the temperature within an athlete’s helmet or headband to the 10th of a degree from below zero to boiling.  

ALERT

When big hits happen or temperatures exceed preset thresholds, notifications are immediately sent to parents, coaches or trainers via text message, email, or the WatchDog mobile app. Alerts can be configured to inform users at desired levels, without distracting them unless there are serious issues detected. This provides maximum flexibility and ultimate protection from undetected concussions or excessive heat.

Sample Alert Events:

  • Alerts parent when impact has occurred over 50.0g via mobile app
  • Alerts coach when two or more impacts have over 40.0g in a week via email.


Mobile App Mockup


Confidentiality:

All alerts are sent ONLY to those designated by coaches and parents to protect an athlete’s personal information and are password protected.

ARCHIVE

All impacts and temperature history are stored in secure cloud servers for future analysis.

Multi-Sport / Multi-Season:

Athletes can use the same sensor across multiple sports for many years. This provides comprehensive data so that medical professionals have more access to an athlete’s impact history.


THE TECH BEHIND IT

WatchDog Sensor Prototype

The WatchDog Sensor has been designed using the Electric Imphttp://www.electricimp.com, a cutting edge hardware development platform for creating the “Internet of Everything.” The Electric Imp platform provides a small form-factor processor, memory, storage space, Wi-Fi transmitter, and API tools necessary to facilitate this project. 

Along with the Imp, we  have incorporated a heavy duty Accelerometer which measures from a few g’s up to 250 g impacts. Since the human body cannot survive more than 150g impacts we are confident that this provides enough range of measurement to satisfy even the most harsh of environments. We also included an onboard temperature sensor that takes continuous readings allowing us to monitor temperature conditions as well as the ability to watch for extreme heat that might cause dehydration or other heat related illnesses that are prevalent in many football programs.

WatchDog Sensor Diagram

A Lithium Ion battery is included as well as recharging hardware allowing this to be a convenient, low cost to operate, and environmentally friendly device. We then enclose all of this inside a waterproof and durable nylon casing that is strong enough to handle the physical conditions but also small enough to avoid interference with the athlete or their sport.

The Sensor transmits data via Wi-Fi to either available networks or personal hotspots through smartphones or standalone internet routers. The data is sent into the Cloud in a secure method that allows us to store in databases for immediate and also long term access for full analysis by trainers or medical professionals.

An iPhone/iPad app is being developed which allows parents, trainers, or athletes, the ability to monitor impact and temperature within seconds from anywhere on the internet. The interface is designed to allow for immediate notifications and easy-to-read graphs showing the severity of recent hits which allows the user the ability to determine if medical treatment is required.


WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP

Currently we have a completed prototype and are looking to take this product to manufacturing. We are in the process of completing the final design that will allow this product to be minimized to a compact form factor easily embedded in an athletic helmet or headband.  Campaign funds will help us finish the final design and set up manufacturing to get this product to market.

story:
Operation: Get Better, Jen!

Over the last year or so, I've gotten to befriend a wonderful person, Jen. As I've gotten to know her, I've come to find out she has a myriad of health problems, coupled with high medical bills. Some friends and I have decided to raise some money for her, even if it's just a bit, to help with things like physical therapy and medication. If we could, we'd love to raise the $30,000 it would cost to help her cover her spinal surgery. But for now, we'll hope to start with enough to make her daily life a little less painful.

 

Here's a story from Jen about her situation

I suppose I could set up the story as a "once upon a time" ordeals but there doesn't seem to be a time where the things just became bad.

My sister and I were really lucky to live with adopted parents who loved us as much as ours did. We never thought of ourselves as adopted or not their blood children. We were always their children despite any problems that might of happened. Neither of us asked them about our birth parents because we were happy and content with the people that loved us so much.

We had many a problems, my sister and I. We wouldn't get along or, she would blame things on me like broken artifacts or spilled milk. Her being 7 years older than me helped her since she had a broader view of the circumstance and I was still rather confused on why they were angry.

She ran away, did drugs, stole money from us, continuously came back only to run away again and drained my parents of their money and living because they loved her. They wanted her to get better. We all did.

Then one day, the phone call came that said she was found dead. From there, her cremation and ceremony took about seven thousand dollars to do. I think that's when all the trouble began.

After Kristy's death, I went on with life ad the remains of trying to get over a broken heart from my boyfriend and I breaking up due to communication problems and the fact that I was too emotional over her loss. He couldn't and didn't understand why I was so sad but that could of been my fault as well.

I was able to go to a College called Palomar in San Marcos California. I really liked the school. It was nice, the teachers were nice and I got to meet five friends who would then be apart of something we never dreamed of.

On a lovely April day, the five of us decide to get in a car and go to one of the near by parks in hopes of studying and getting some of our Japanese homework finished for a final coming up. We never made it to the park.

I'm still fuzzy on the details since I was instantly knocked out but, the driver was trying to show off changing lanes far too quickly and ended up losing control of the car and flipped us over about six times until we finally came to rest at the train tracks outside our school. [Image of the wreckage.]

While we were all rushed to the hospital, it felt like I had nothing too wrong with me. After the accident I went on with life as normal. Got a job, kept going to school, moved in with my new boyfriend[a survivor of our car crash] and things seemed great. I kept having small pains in my back but since I was never X-Rayed or MRI-ed after the car crash like I should of been, I never knew there was a developing problem.

A couple of years go by and the back pains are getting worse. I had to quit that job from pain and moved back home to help parents with payments on the house or else they'd lose it.  I tried to get another job locally where I am but as I was there one day, leaning over the counter to read up on something, I felt the first severe pain.

I couldn't lift myself up. I was leaned over and my spine would not allow me to lean up at all. It felt locked in place and while my boss asked me to come over for a moment I just winced, smiled and nodded and tried my best to go over there despite the pain. I couldn't push myself up completely but I tried. 

I worked there for about a week. Every night I would come home in tears because of my spine. I tried to just shake it off and go back the next day only to have a repeat of the previous where my back would lock up and I'd be immobile for a good five minutes. Because of that I had to quit there. My parents and my boyfriend didn't want me to have to continuously come home in tears.

The back aches got worse and gradually worse. I didn't have money to get insurance so I had spent most of my time going to a free clinic where I was simply given tramadol and flexeril, muscle relaxers. However, Tramadol is a narcotic drug. I've been on it for about 3 years. Because of that, if I go 15 hours without a tramadol I have severe withdraw attacks.

The medicine helps but knowing I have to be on a clock schedule for the medicine felt kind of like a downer for me. One night I was out of them and while sleep wasn't easy, I did get some rest. However, my boyfriend noticed my body was acting strange. I would have to twist and turn and lash my arms out and about because they were so tense from the narcotic. I would smash my shoulder in to the closet door and twist my arm around as if I were attempting to break it. All of that would go away once I had my medicine though. And the medicine DID help a lot. It still does. I'm still on it as of now.

Happiness came in the form of a hobby known as Cosplay. I had made some horns for my Ragnarok Online costumes but apparently they were a hit and a friend off-handedly suggested I tried making the Homestuck Troll Horns. Not wanting to step on toes, I asked the creator, Andrew Hussie for permission first. Within about 30 minutes of asking, he wrote back and told me that it was great! He'd be happy for me to which I thought was extra nice of him. That May, I was able to sell them at Fanime-Con and we made a nice deal of money.

Since then, Andrew allowed me to sell under his Copyright. I was able to do the Cosplay troll horns for those who commissioned me. The money I had set aside that would only be used once their commissions were mailed out, were used for my day to day life. Eating, medication, doctor visits[ Free clinics charged a fee of 35$ per visit] and to help my parents with their life. However, because of the kind of stress that came with it, I'd have to shrug off all the negative comments and anger people would send my way saying that I was cheating Andrew or doing illegal activity.

Thankfully, a day came where my hopes were answered. After being turned away from every insurance group a group in California known as PCIP finally took me in. They take in those with per-excisting medical conditions. However, the price for every month is 140$. That's still a little much for someone who has no job.

However, I was able to finally get seen by a doctor who then referred me to a physical therapist. I was able to do hydro therapy which felt wonderful but every. EVERY. session is 80$. Again, as someone with no job, 80$ was a lot per-visit.

The day came where I was finally able to get my MRI to see what was going on in my spine. What they found has put me in a set back.

At the base of my spine I have two disks that are crushed together, pinching the nerves of my spinal cord that makes sitting, standing, laying, anything uncomfortable. I have to constantly be careful of how I move and how I arrange myself. I can't walk for long or the pinching worsens. Near the top of my spine, I have bone spurs beginning to shoot out. For those who don't know, bone spurs are build ups of Calcium that begin to come out and look like spikes on my spine.

After that, the doctor perscriped pain therapy for aid before they have to take the drastic measures of spinal therapy. [It will be done they just want to do as little as possible.] Spinal repair could cost anything from eight thousand dollars to thirty thousand dollars with therapy afterwords. Needless to say I have a way to go before I can get that fixt.

My boyfriend got a job for us. He's been working really hard for the money he's earned and most of it goes to my parents so they're able to continue living in their house. Both are retired nearing their mid 70's and because they're in such bad shape they've contemplated going back in to the work field. My mom has gone to get an interview to be a pizza delivery person and that crushes me.  I don't want her out at night making deliveries to places she doesn't know. She's 4'9 and far more fragile than me. Dad does consulting work with a friend of his but that's about a thousand dollars every two months which goes away quickly with bills.

One day, getting on the on ramp to the freeway, out of nowhere it seemed, a semi-truck clipped the bumper of  my car and caught it. The car was then dragged along the left side of the semi-truck until it was turned to face towards oncoming traffic. The entire left part of the car had been utterly destroyed and the Semi-truck dragged it for about 4 blocks. [ Image 1 Image 2 ---images of my car.]

Since then, my car has been taken to the junk yard and stripped for parts. The Semi-truck is trying to say it was our fault and a settlement may not be reached until four to five months. This has left me without a car and without a car I've had to halt my pain therapy, physical therapy and I've since stopped doing the commissions for Homestuck Horns after a series of people told me to put a gun in my mouth or that when I get in a car crash next time, to actually do the world a favor and die.

Dad has since found out he's in the 75% chance of having a heart attack due to his genes. My grandmother had one in 1973 and I never got to meet her. She had clogged arteries that had resulted in such and now he's facing the same fate. He's doing what he can and we try and work on Wii Fit together even if I have to be extra careful sometimes.

We're still behind on payments for the house. I've begun selling off some of my possessions and so has my mother. She had taken my grandmother's wedding rings, designed by my grandfather to give to her, and has sold them to get money. She's also begun selling other things like necklaces and earrings my grandfather had given her. It kills me to see them selling their memories but in desperate times you do things, I suppose.

I'm trying to keep my head up. I'm trying to think better days will come but right now, it seems cheaper for a funeral than to keep going. I'll still do what I can, if not for myself then for the parents that took me in and raised me as their own.

 

What this means to us

Our goal is to raise $1000, which should be good for a few physical therapy sessions, as well as help pay for her insurance. Anything more raised than that, and hopefully she'll be able to get more of the therapy, medication, tests, and procedures done she needs, and she can live a normal life.

 

You can also see (and maybe comission) some artwork from her at her deviantArt
story_txt:
Operation: Get Better, Jen!
Over the last year or so, I've gotten to befriend a wonderful person, Jen. As I've gotten to know her, I've come to find out she has a myriad of health problems, coupled with high medical bills. Some friends and I have decided to raise some money for her, even if it's just a bit, to help with things like physical therapy and medication. If we could, we'd love to raise the $30,000 it would cost to help her cover her spinal surgery. But for now, we'll hope to start with enough to make her daily life a little less painful.
 
Here's a story from Jen about her situation

I suppose I could set up the story as a "once upon a time" ordeals but there doesn't seem to be a time where the things just became bad.My sister and I were really lucky to live with adopted parents who loved us as much as ours did. We never thought of ourselves as adopted or not their blood children. We were always their children despite any problems that might of happened. Neither of us asked them about our birth parents because we were happy and content with the people that loved us so much.We had many a problems, my sister and I. We wouldn't get along or, she would blame things on me like broken artifacts or spilled milk. Her being 7 years older than me helped her since she had a broader view of the circumstance and I was still rather confused on why they were angry. She ran away, did drugs, stole money from us, continuously came back only to run away again and drained my parents of their money and living because they loved her. They wanted her to get better. We all did.Then one day, the phone call came that said she was found dead. From there, her cremation and ceremony took about seven thousand dollars to do. I think that's when all the trouble began.After Kristy's death, I went on with life ad the remains of trying to get over a broken heart from my boyfriend and I breaking up due to communication problems and the fact that I was too emotional over her loss. story:
Bitmec is a digital health system that delivers quality, affordable medical care to underserved rural areas. The Bitmec system consists of three pillars that are connected through an interactive web portal: (i) patients located in rural communities; (ii) a network of itinerant community health workers; (iii) a network of remote doctors connected to the Bitmec portal.

Bitmec's network of health workers links patients living in communities without access to healthcare and a network of remote doctors. Bitmec's network of health workers links patients living in communities without access to healthcare and a network of remote doctors. During the first interaction between the Bitmec health worker and the patient, the health worker registers the patient in the Bitmec database, including demographic information, medical history and other relevant information. Once the registration is complete, the health worker enters the symptoms reported by the patient and takes vital signs. Once the health worker completes the information collection and symptom reporting steps, the health worker presses the send button and the platform sends the case to a remote doctor.
 

Doctor Network:

A network of remote doctors assists patients through an embedded video system.  The network consists mainly of young doctors starting their careers who don’t have recurring patients and their own practice.

Each doctor connects to the Bitmec portal and prior to the start of the video consultation, the doctor has the opportunity to review the case. During the video consultation, the platform provides the doctor with applications to generate medical notes, medical prescriptions and laboratory orders.

WHO’s International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems ("ICD"). The diagnoses feed a database and allow statistical analysis. The doctor's portal contains a calendar function and a patient database. The doctor can schedule an appointment and generate a referral to other doctors within Bitmec or a conventional health center.  Communication with the patient is carried out through SMS messages.

    

Bitmec's Story

It began with one of the founders (David) personal experience. After undergoing major back surgery and learning to walk again, a sense of purpose was born within him; trying to help others who have not been blessed with the opportunity he had of having access to the best medical care he could have ever hoped for.


After deciding to move forward with this purpose, an incredible group of cofounders was born, all with the idea of wanting to bring change for those most in need. Through extensive research and understanding of the barriers that exist for rural communities in developing economies to access to quality medical care, the team created a solution that brings healthcare directly to the community.

 

What We Have Achieved

 

The Impact

Currently we are in the first phase of implementing our digital health system in marginalized areas of the population through 2 different focus points which are corporate and retail. So far we have focused our operational efforts in 6 different areas in Guatemala which are Quetzaltenango, San Marcos, Retalhuleu, Suchitepéquez, Jutiapa and Zacapa together with our strategic partner in the area who is a retailer chain in this part of the country. Our next step is to expand our focus directly in to communities, which is where we will invest the money raised through this campaign. We will focus on providing our health services to communities far away from urban centers which do not have access to medical care and thus have a huge need for an integral solution like Bitmec.

In a second phase, we are contemplating the idea of incorporating educative modules that will allow for the development of more human resources to offer our services.

It is important to note that Bitmec not only focuses on the healthcare service it provides, it also impacts society by creating new jobs for local health practitioners who have the cultural and linguistical characteristics of the communities where we offer our services. Improving quality of life through more services, developing workforce and increasing monthly incomes for our team members in these communities helps prevent more people from migrating to look for a better life.

 

Help Us Give Medical Care To All!

We are raising money in order to scale the amount of people Bitmec is able to impact. With your support, we would complete another 2,400 consultations as we will be able to hire more doctors and health promotores in order to scale the impact significantly. This benchmark will also help us understand even better our market.

  • Funding Goal: $30,000 to achieve 2400 medical consultations.
  • Buy our Guatemalan unique Wakami bracelets to help us! Check out the beautiful designs, handmade by women artisans in Guatemala​.
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, funding received will be used for the consultations equal to the money achieved.

 

Our Team

David Barac, Co-founder & CEO

David has several years of experience as a technology startup entrepreneur.  Previously, he was Co-Founder of Acquapak, a startup that develops technology that facilitates the transport of flowers from their point of origin to the final point of sale.  Having undergone major back surgery that forced him to learn to walk again, among other complications, David decided to turn his energies as an entrepreneur to help other people have access to quality medical care like he had.  It was at this moment that the idea of Bitmec was born, and David recruited a group of experienced Co-Founders.  David has a B.S in International Economics from Suffolk University in Boston, Massachusetts.

 

José V. Ordóñez, Cofounder

José has more than 20 years of experience as a private equity and venture capital investor, senior banker and an entrepreneur.  He is currently Managing Director of SEAF Caribbean Sea Clean Energy Fund, a private equity fund that invests in renewable energy and cleantech in Central America and the Caribbean.  He is Co-Founder of several cleantech and technology startups, including HYBRICO Energy Technologies, Ltd., a company that designs and manufactures "hybrid power" equipment for telecommunication sites, Chopinmol.com, an e-commerce platform focused on Latin American immigrants living in the US and Bitmec, an online platform providing healthcare services in rural communities.  José is Senior Advisor to Kingo Energy, a Guatemalan startup that offers prepaid solar energy in off-grid communities.  Previously, José was Managing Director of US Renewables Group, a private equity fund specializing in renewable energy investments and CEO of Pan American Hydro Corporation, a Canadian company that develops small hydroelectric power plants in Latin America.  He was Managing Partner of Grevillea Capital, a Spanish investment banking and private equity boutique firm focused on the European renewable energy market.  He was CEO of Global3 Energía, a Spanish clean energy generation company owned by ArcLight Capital, an energy private equity fund and Head of the Latin American Energy Group at Citigroup in NY, where he completed more than $12 billion in M&A and capital raising transactions.  José is Co-Founder and President of the Guatemalan Venture Capital Association.  José has an MBA from the Stanford Graduate School of Business, a JD from Stanford Law School and a B.A. in Economics (magna cum laude) from the University of Maryland.

 

Lorena Chacón, Co-founder and Marketing Director

Lorena has more than 18 years of experience advising and implementing rural economic development projects in multiple fields.  She has worked with international development agencies in health, nutrition and food security projects throughout Guatemala.  She has an extensive network of community workers throughout Guatemala and several countries in Central America and South America.   Lorena has in-depth knowledge of the structure and operations of the Guatemalan national healthcare system.  She has authored multiple research and market studies relating to social and behavior change.  Lorena is a leading consultant to several international development aid organizations, having worked in over 30 projects.  Currently, Lorena is CEO of Sincronia, a Guatemala-based development consulting firm, Executive Director the National Center for Disaster and Development Research and Information (CENACIDE), a Guatemalan NGO, Social and Behavior Change Consultant for MASFRIJOL, a USAID/Michigan State University food security project being implemented in Guatemala.  Lorena has a PhD in Social Research (magna cum laude) from Pan American University in Guatemala and a PhD in Communications (magna cum laude) from San Carlos University in Guatemala, as well as postgraduate certificates in Health from San Carlos University, Andragogy from Cadiz University (Spain), Social Marketing (University of Ohio – Universidad del Valle, Guatemala, joint program), Social Behavior and Change Communication (University of Ohio – Universidad del Valle, Guatemala and Universidad del Norte, Colombia joint program).  She has a BA in Communications Sciences (cum laude) and a Masters degree in Communication for Development (cum laude), both from San Carlos University and a technical degree in Advertising (summa cum laude), also from San Carlos University.

 

Alvaro Rivera, Co-Founder and Medical Director

Alvaro has over five years of experience in community medicine and public health.  He has implemented multiple research projects and innovative programs in collaboration with local and international organizations.  His work has been primarily focused on prevention of chronic non-communicable diseases in indigenous and rural communities of Guatemala.  Alvaro has an MD from San Carlos University in Guatemala, a Masters degree in Public Health from the Hebrew University of Jerusalem and a Diploma in Health Services Innovation from INCAE Business School in Costa Rica.

 

Risks & Challenges

Our biggest challenge is our service acceptance by the people who will be using Bitmec, we are using an accurate methodology with surveys that mix quantitative and qualitative data. Surveys and interviews are being conducted respectively to know the degree of acceptance and interest, as well as the perception and tendency of the users of the service.

The indicators:

  • % use of health services
  • % frequency of medical care
  • % platform acceptance

The categories:

  • Satisfaction of the medical service
  • Perception of acceptance of the service
  • Empathy with the local promoter

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • You can visit our webpage https://bitmec.com/ to know more and share our cause!
  • Follow us @ facebook & instagram and share!
  • Remember you can also use Indiegogo share tools if you want to help us spread the word!

Our Team
David Barac, Co-founder & CEO
David has several years of experience as a technology startup entrepreneur.  Previously, he was Co-Founder of Acquapak, a startup that develops technology that facilitates the transport of flowers from their point of origin to the final point of sale.  Having undergone major back surgery that forced him to learn to walk again, among other complications, David decided to turn his energies as an entrepreneur to help other people have access to quality medical care like he had.  It was at this moment that the idea of Bitmec was born, and David recruited a group of experienced Co-Founders.  David has a B.S in International Economics from Suffolk University in Boston, Massachusetts.
 
José V. Ordóñez, Cofounder
José has more than 20 years of experience as a private equity and venture capital investor, senior banker and an entrepreneur.  He is currently Managing Director of SEAF Caribbean Sea Clean Energy Fund, a private equity fund that invests in renewable energy and cleantech in Central America and the Caribbean.  He is Co-Founder of several cleantech and technology startups, including HYBRICO Energy Technologies, Ltd., a company that designs and manufactures "hybrid power" equipment for telecommunication sites, Chopinmol.com, an e-commerce platform focused on Latin American immigrants living in the US and Bitmec, an online platform providing healthcare services in rural communities.  José is Senior Advisor to Kingo Energy, a Guatemalan startup that offers prepaid solar energy in off-grid communities.  Previously, José was Managing Director of US Renewables Group, a private equity fund specializing in renewable energy investments and CEO of Pan American Hydro Corporation, a Canadian company that develops small hydroelectric power plants in Latin America.  He was Managing Partner of Grevillea Capital, a Spanish investment banking and private equity boutique firm focused on the European renewable energy market.  He was CEO of Global3 Energía, a Spanish clean energy generation company owned by ArcLight Capital, an energy private equity fund and Head of the Latin American Energy Group at Citigroup in NY, where he completed more than $12 billion in M&A and capital raising transactions.  José is Co-Founder and President of the Guatemalan Venture Capital Association.  José has an MBA from the Stanford Graduate School of Business, a JD from Stanford Law School and a B.A. in Economics (magna cum laude) from the University of Maryland.
 
Lorena Chacón, Co-founder and Marketing Director
Lorena has more than 18 years of experience advising and implementing rural economic development projects in multiple fields.  She has worked with international development agencies in health, nutrition and food security projects throughout Guatemala.  She has an extensive network of community workers throughout Guatemala and several countries in Central America and South America.   Lorena has in-depth knowledge of the structure and operations of the Guatemalan national healthcare system.  She has authored multiple research and market studies relating to social and behavior change.  Lorena is a leading consultant to several international development aid organizations, having worked in over 30 projects.  Currently, Lorena is CEO of Sincronia, a Guatemala-based development consulting firm, Executive Director the National Center for Disaster and Development Research and Information (CENACIDE), a Guatemalan NGO, Social and Behavior Change Consultant for MASFRIJOL, a USAID/Michigan State University food security project being implemented in Guatemala.  Lorena has a PhD in Social Research (magna cum laude) from Pan American University in Guatemala and a PhD in Communications (magna cum laude) from San Carlos University in Guatemala, as well as postgraduate certificates in Health from San Carlos University, Andragogy from Cadiz University (Spain), Social Marketing (University of Ohio – Universidad del Valle, Guatemala, joint program), Social Behavior and Change Communication (University of Ohio – Universidad del Valle, Guatemala and Universidad del Norte, Colombia joint program).  She has a BA in Communications Sciences (cum laude) and a Masters degree in Communication for Development (cum laude), both from San Carlos University and a technical degree in Advertising (summa cum laude), also from San Carlos University.
 
Alvaro Rivera, Co-Founder and Medical Director
Alvaro has over five years of experience in community medicine and public health.  He has implemented multiple research projects and innovative programs in collaboration with local and international organizations.  His work has been primarily focused on prevention of chronic non-communicable diseases in indigenous and rural communities of Guatemala.  Alvaro has an MD from San Carlos University in Guatemala, a Masters degree in Public Health from the Hebrew University of Jerusalem and a Diploma in Health Services Innovation from INCAE Business School in Costa Rica.
 
Risks & Challenges
Our biggest challenge is our service acceptance by the people who will be using Bitmec, we are using an accurate methodology with surveys that mix quantitative and qualitative data. Surveys and interviews are being conducted respectively to know the degree of acceptance and interest, as well as the perception and tendency of the users of the service.
The indicators:

% use of health services
% frequency of medical care
% platform acceptance

The categories:

Satisfaction of the medical service
Perception of acceptance of the service
Empathy with the local promoter

 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can visit our webpage https://bitmec.com/ to know more and share our cause!
Follow us @ facebook & instagram and share!
Remember you can also use Indiegogo share tools if you want to help us spread the word!

story:
3 Goldfields athletes - Olivia Black, Rosey Pearce & Shelby Dickhart have been selected in the WALA State Team to represent WA in Singapore in July 2014

Olivia will be competing in Long Jump, Rosey in Hurdles and Shelby in Javelin as well as possible other events 

All 3 girls have been a part of Eastern Goldfields Little Athletics Centre since they were young

Please help support these 3 talented girls and donate today

story:
Feb 16th the Beautification Project Celebrated its Birthday!!!

We wanted to Thank everyone for all of the support this year!

Together we can and will make a difference.
Planting grass in numerous locations to stop and control Erosion on our sand based course.
Purchased a truck to use for hauling and course maintenance, its already earned its place in the SFDGC Fam.
Erosion control on pathway on Hole 12 needs more work.
Drain rock placed around tee pads#4 #5 #7 to stop flooding and mud tees.
The TEMPLE structure on Hole #11
The "Great Wall" on hole #6 needs to be finished.
Improved tee box area on #12
Drastically reduced play through time on 11,12,14 with proper maintenance of the hill side.That is now covered in GRASS!!!
New Tee Signs!
More seating!
Erosion control tier on 18 to save main tree by the C pin.
...and last but certainly not least the course is looking GREEN,GREEN,GREEN!!

But we're not done.

Starting the new year we need tier work on #3 (all ready in place) #11/#16 will be my next main focus .I want to finish the great wall on #6.add Drain rock to all the tees in need.There are more tee signs to be replaced, constant maintenance due to ever-increasing foot traffic as daily new disc golfers explore their obsession, and the necessarily vigilant watch over erosion spots on the course.

What we need:

Support through funding to keep the workers on the course, providing for and serving the rapidly growing disc golf community in San Francisco and the greater Northern California region.
Through their tireless work and dedication, the Golden Gate Park Disc Golf Course will be the premiere free public course in the United States and the standard by which all other courses, private and public, will be judged in the future.

story:
Short Summary

Kyle and his son are delaing with health issues and Kyle and his family have been through a lot dealing with cancer.

What We Need & What You Get

Kyle entered a contest to win an HTC ONE and like many I was touched by the video. I want to make sure he is able to get the phone even if he doesn't win the contest. If he does win the contest, I'm sure this money will come in handy.

I have two small children and I just couldn't not do something. I will be contributing and paying the fee charged by indiegogo (at least up to the goal of $1,000) so Kyle and his family get all the money raised. I will also make the first contributuion.

This is my first time using this site so I really hope it's a success. Thanks for contributing!

story:
Like ZeeMee on Facebook

Press Coverage:

Crunchwear: Zansors Wearable Sleep Sensor allows you to measure your ’sleep personality’

TechZone360: Zansors Creates New Sleep Patch that Measures Your Sleep Personality

We all have moods and personalities—but what about when we sleep? Is there such a thing as a sleep personality? Does your “sleep mood” at night affect your mood in the morning? How is who we are when we’re asleep connected to who we are during the day? Just like there is a personality type matrix called Myers-Briggs Type Indicator, can we invent a "sleep personality" type?

Welcome to project ZeeMee, brought to you by the team at Zansors. We hope you’ll join us in developing something totally cool and different—a “wearable” sensor that detects and gathers information about how people sleep. Smart and sophisticated from a technology point of view, yet simple to use and understand, ZeeMee taps into our fascination with the mystery of sleep and dreams—and the very real impact sleep has on our daily lives:

  • Sleep is something we all do – animals too! We spend much of our lives sleeping, yet in many ways it’s a mystery.
  • The way you sleep is meaningful. Even when you’re not dreaming, your sleep is full of patterns and signs.
  • Your sleep helps define who you are and how you behave every day. It’s part of your personality. It’s profoundly connected to your mood and your outlook.

Do you remember mood rings? Well, Zansors wants to democratize our technology and create a fun, easy-to-use device that reports on your sleep in the morning—so you get a “sleep personality” score that you can talk about and compare with others. Are you a Green-2 (we call that Black Bear); Yellow-3 (Siamese House Cat) or are you a Red-4 or 5 (Sloth or Shark)?  See our matrix below for some of our other "scores." 

With your help, we can bring ZeeMee to life.

We are a start-up based in Washington D.C called Zansors. A few of our Z-Crew superheros (tech nerds who love to make/build) key to this project are:  

The Z-Crew came together a year ago because we love technology and the mystery of sleep. We came up with the concept of ZeeMee because we were all curious about our own sleep personalities and figured other people would would be interested as well.  With that ZeeMee was born!

WHAT DOES IT DO

  • ZeeMee is a wireless sleep patch powered by micro-sensors. It’s comfortable and easy to sleep with.
  • When you wake up, ZeeMee will tell you how you slept. It displays a color (green, yellow, or red) and a number (1 to 5).
  • The color is based on the way you breathed during the night.
  • The number is based your motion—how much you tossed and turned.

ZeeMee's color and number give a unique "sleep personality" - see the score table below

Knowing your sleep personality can be helpful for you and others: Stay away from the Red-5! How is the Yellow-3 going to act around me? You will discover how your mood and temperament during sleep affects your day - and vice versa.  We've developed our own "sleep personality" type for you to compare for fun.

What unique sleep personality do you wake up to?

OUR VISION

Zansors builds high-quality, low-cost micro/nano sensor platforms. These sensors are the same ones in your car (air bag sensor, tire pressure sensors), iPhone, or Microsoft Kinect.

Our knowledge and expertise is not just in sensors, but also in both software analytics and design. We have an expert team exploring new ways to make technology platforms more creative, easy to use, and relevant to our daily lives.

ZeeMee represents the best of our technology married to the best of our creative thinking—a great way to bring innovation to unexpected places.  

KEY FEATURES

  • Simple and easy-to-use: You just wake up and look at the color and number readout for your sleep personality.
  • Super hardware technology inside: We packed 99 parts in a small space, including micro-controller, sensors, and battery.
  • Super software algorithms built inside: We have studied breathing and motion to build unique algorithms to give you your sleep personality score.
  • Small: The ZeeMee patch is 1.5 inch x 2.0 inch.
  • Comfortable: Feels hardly there, like a band-aid on your neck.
  • Rugged, but kind to your skin: We use special adhesives from our supplier that are used for band-aids or dermal patches.
  • Affordable: Our smart team found the "special-sauce" to democratize this technology.

HOW YOU CAN HELP

We need your help to produce the first batch of ZeeMee sensor patches and democratize the technology. Not only do we need your financial backing, but we need curious and technology savvy users ready and willing to explore their sleep personality using sensor technology.  We've done our homework too - we made physical prototypes and tested with our special software.

 Indiegogo community can complete the ZeeMee project!

ZeeMee prototype is small, on our adhesive pad, and our Jill Spaeth showing the easy peel-and-stick patch

Jill placing the prototype on her neck and showing that she is ready to sleep and score

In the above photos, you can see a physical prototype that was fabricated at our foundry and tested (while person sleeping). The size is small and can be attached to a specialized adhesive.

YOUR HELP WILL GET US TO THE FINISH LINE and ready for production with our beautiful, final design!  Here's what we have completed since March 2012:  

  • Developed the sleep score algorithms corresponding to colors and numbers based on breathing and motion patterns during sleep
  • Bill of materials for hardware components created
  • Electrical schematics completed
  • Embedded/firmware software completed
  • Prototype developed at a semiconductor foundry and professional testing conducted
  • Supply chain and logistics established - not in our garage but in a professional space
  • Identified the right adhesives by an expert firm in the space
  • Consulted with experts in sleep

With your pledge of $75 or more, you will be one of the first to explore this new world of sleep personality using sensor technology.    

WHAT YOU GET

Starting with a pledge of $75 or more you get the fully assembled wireless sensor patch called ZeeMee (see final version picture below).  You take the ZeeMee out of the box, press the button and have fun discovering your sleep personality using sensors.  

ZeeMee's Hardware

Classic:  If you support the CLASSIC, then there is only one piece and it'sZeeMee.  No other external parts besides some extra sticky pads so you have fresh one to use each night.  The Zansors team has put together 99 parts that go on the miniaturized PC board.  The hardware includes micro-controllers for software processing, semiconductor circuits, micro-sensors for measuring breathing and motion, and memory to store your sleep personality data.

Special Edition:  If you support the SPECIAL EDITION, then you will not only get the ZeeMee but you will get a special cord that allows for recharging.

ZeeMee's Size  

A picture is worth a thousand words. Need we say more?

ZeeMee wireless sensor patch - size comparison

ZeeMee's Software

All of the software is built inside the hardware.  If you support the CLASSIC, just stick it on and go to sleep. You do not have to download anything.  The software to measure breathing sounds and motion were developed by our Chief Data Science Officer who has a Ph.D. in biostatistics; he made the proprietary algorithms.  We also have an embedded/firmware software engineer to make sure the software works 100% with hardware. 

If you support the SPECIAL EDITION, you get a free app (sleep log) that will sync with your ZeeMee so you can read your sleep personality data real-time (second-by-second) like stock charts or sports stats. Our Information Architect guru and software developers are designing a beautiful experience for you.  The Z-team will post updates on this site on the progress of this app before the April delivery.  This very same team made the app called Sleep Champ based on University of Michigan research so we know how to make apps and get approval from Apple and Google.   

Specs

  • Size: 1.5 inch x 2.0 inch (2.5 cm x 5.0 cm); 0.1 inch (2.5 mm) thick
  • Weight:  0.1 ounces (4.0 grams)
  • Battery:  3 volts; coin battery that you can replace
  • Display:  LED lights (Green, yellow, red) and numerical values 1- 5  

If you donate $22 to help launch ZeeMee, then you can collect some swag! Not only is this a water bottle, but impress your friends with it's detachable wine cup for those fancy occasions. We throw in a ZeeMee sticker too!

Unique bottle design by our friends at Dopper plus ZeeMee sticker

WHO WE ARE

Zansors is focused on creating the next generation sensor platform integrated with software analytics and design.  We want to democratize our sensor technology and make it available inexpensively to all.  There are eight core members at Zansors and we are an integrated team with experience in User Interface and User Experience (UI/UX); Design, Data Science, Software Engineering, Bioengineering, and Business.  Our smart and energetic team believes in 100% quality.  

Z-Crew Team "working hard and playing hard."

Z-Crew Team working

Jill Spaeth is our Chief Creative Officer and she is leading this ZeeMeeproject.  She is a leading force in the Washington D.C. area when it comes to design and creativity.  She has been a featured panel speaker on design for several years at DC Week where local entrepreneurs come together. Jill recently completed her term as the youngest President of AIGA DC, the 6th largest AIGA Chapter in the nation with over 900 members. She managed a board of 23 dedicated volunteers that brought meaningful programs and initiatives in design to the local community. In 2007 she helped to start the AIGA DC Design Continuum Fund which has awarded over $10K in scholarships to local design students. Outside of design, Jill is an avid road cyclist and typically covers 130 miles by bike per week. She recently raised over $2,500 for Pelotonia, a grass roots bike tour in Ohion with one goal: END CANCER.   

Abhijit Dasgupta, Ph.D. is our Chief Data Science Officer and he looks at all data from breathing to motion and builds algorithms relevant to our sleep personality color and number scores.  He has a Ph.D. from University of Washington and has been a faculty member at Thomas Jefferson University and advisor to National Institutes of Health (NIH).  His love for data can be genetic data or digital data (0's and 1's).  He is a leading organizer of "Big Data" Meetups in the Washington, D.C. area. 

Dave Warner is our Chief Technology Officer and leading the technical aspects of our platform.  He has 12+ years in software and hardware development in the auto industry besides a M.B.A. from University of Michigan and B.S. in electrical engineering degree.  He has had direct impact on electronic engine control modules, infotainment radio displays, and digital satellite radio firmware.  He's delivered solutions to Ford Motor Company, Lycoming Engines, Sirius Satellite Radios, Panasonic, and Sony.  His past work experiences include travelling to manufacturing hubs like to Mexico and India to make sure projects are delivered on time.  

Ranjit Das, M.D. is our Chief Innovation Officer and guides the team with cutting-edge ideas for the sensor platform.  He keeps an eye on science and technology trends and determines how to apply them for real-world use.  He believes innovative ideas come from being on the "front-lines" with technology users and understanding their experiences. As an avid follower of sci-fi movies, his ideas are imagined "out of this world" but grounded for our current state of technology innovation.   

We are excited to present these stars to you besides the other team members and partners.  Also, key to the team is Donna Oetzel who is our Chief Storyteller and she recognized the importance to combine the concepts of sleep and personality using technologies.

Some highlights about Zansors:

  • Won competitive federal government award in the six figures
  • Formal licensing partnership with University of Michigan in July 2012
  • Launched a sleep app called Sleep Champ in Aug. 2012 in collaboration with national sleep expert Dr. Ron Chervin
  • Invited member of President Obama's Startup America Partnership
  • Invited member of the United Nations Foundation's mHealth Alliance
  • Strong proprietary position on our inventions
  • Founded in 2010 in the metro Washington, D.C. area

It's an honor to serve you.  In order to deliver success, we have recruited amazing partners not only to reach success but show you credibility with the high-caliber partners. Our partners are amazing folks and we hope you visit them and work with them:

  • Amplify Public Affairs:  David Lee, Elena Berger, and Kevin Reid are helping with all aspects of the creative experience and story-telling.  They come from a dedicated firm helping us "amplify" our call for help from you!

  • Semiconductor Hybrid Assembly:  The semiconductor hardware assembly including electronics and integrated circuits and testing are done at SHA based in Wixom, Michigan who has been a reliable, high-quality supplier for auto and defense industries, and 
  • Prototype Production Inc. (PPI):  PPI's CTO Ben Feldman and Greg Paulsen are helping us with the prototyping (final look-and-feel) in addition to the assembly and logistics (shipping and warehousing).  They have state-of-the art machines and experienced staff.  If the federal government goes to them, then we know they can get the job done.

 Benjamin Feldman - Chief Technology Officer

Weight:  0.1 ounces (4.0 grams)

Battery:  3 volts; coin battery that you can replace

Display:  LED lights (Green, yellow, red) and numerical values 1- 5  

If you donate $22 to help launch ZeeMee, then you can collect some swag! Not only is this a water bottle, but impress your friends with it's detachable wine cup for those fancy occasions. We throw in a ZeeMee sticker too!

Unique bottle design by our friends at Dopper plus ZeeMee sticker
WHO WE ARE
Zansors is focused on creating the next generation sensor platform integrated with software analytics and design.  We want to democratize our sensor technology and make it available inexpensively to all.  There are eight core members at Zansors and we are an integrated team with experience in User Interface and User Experience (UI/UX); Design, Data Science, Software Engineering, Bioengineering, and Business.  Our smart and energetic team believes in 100% quality.  

Z-Crew Team "working hard and playing hard."

Z-Crew Team working
Jill Spaeth is our Chief Creative Officer and she is leading this ZeeMeeproject.  She is a leading force in the Washington D.C. area when it comes to design and creativity.  She has been a featured panel speaker on design for several years at DC Week where local entrepreneurs come together. Jill recently completed her term as the youngest President of AIGA DC, the 6th largest AIGA Chapter in the nation with over 900 members. She managed a board of 23 dedicated volunteers that brought meaningful programs and initiatives in design to the local community. In 2007 she helped to start the AIGA DC Design Continuum Fund which has awarded over $10K in scholarships to local design students. Outside of design, Jill is an avid road cyclist and typically covers 130 miles by bike per week. She recently raised over $2,500 for Pelotonia, a grass roots bike tour in Ohion with one goal: END CANCER.   
Abhijit Dasgupta, Ph.D. is our Chief Data Science Officer and he looks at all data from breathing to motion and builds algorithms relevant to our sleep personality color and number scores.  He has a Ph.D. from University of Washington and has been a faculty member at Thomas Jefferson University and advisor to National Institutes of Health (NIH).  His love for data can be genetic data or digital data (0's and 1's).  He is a leading organizer of "Big Data" Meetups in the Washington, D.C. area. 
Dave Warner is our Chief Technology Officer and leading the technical aspects of our platform.  He has 12+ years in software and hardware development in the auto industry besides a M.B.A. from University of Michigan and B.S. in electrical engineering degree.  He has had direct impact on electronic engine control modules, infotainment radio displays, and digital satellite radio firmware.  He's delivered solutions to Ford Motor Company, Lycoming Engines, Sirius Satellite Radios, Panasonic, and Sony.  His past work experiences include travelling to manufacturing hubs like to Mexico and India to make sure projects are delivered on time.  
Ranjit Das, M.D. is our Chief Innovation Officer and guides the team with cutting-edge ideas for the sensor platform.  He keeps an eye on science and technology trends and determines how to apply them for real-world use.  He believes innovative ideas come from being on the "front-lines" with technology users and understanding their experiences. As an avid follower of sci-fi movies, his ideas are imagined "out of this world" but grounded for our current state of technology innovation.   
We are excited to present these stars to you besides the other team members and partners.  Also, key to the team is Donna Oetzel who is our Chief Storyteller and she recognized the importance to combine the concepts of sleep and personality using technologies.
Some highlights about Zansors:

Won competitive federal government award in the six figures
Formal licensing partnership with University of Michigan in July 2012
Launched a sleep app called Sleep Champ in Aug. 2012 in collaboration with national sleep expert Dr. Ron Chervin

Invited member of President Obama's Startup America Partnership

Invited member of the United Nations Foundation's mHealth Alliance

Strong proprietary position on our inventions
Founded in 2010 in the metro Washington, D.C. area

It's an honor to serve you.  In order to deliver success, we have recruited amazing partners not only to reach success but show you credibility with the high-caliber partners. Our partners are amazing folks and we hope you visit them and work with them:


Amplify Public Affairs:  David Lee, Elena Berger, and Kevin Reid are helping with all aspects of the creative experience and story-telling.  They come from a dedicated firm helping us "amplify" our call for help from you!




Semiconductor Hybrid Assembly:  The semiconductor hardware assembly including electronics and integrated circuits and testing are done at SHA based in Wixom, Michigan who has been a reliable, high-quality supplier for auto and defense industries, and 

Prototype Production Inc. (PPI):  PPI's CTO Ben Feldman and Greg Paulsen are helping us with the prototyping (final look-and-feel) in addition to the assembly and logistics (shipping and warehousing).  They have state-of-the art machines and experienced staff.  If the federal government goes to them, then we know they can get the job done.



 Benjamin Feldman - Chief Technology Officer

story:
Years ago machinist Andrew Crowder created the perfect gravity smoking piece. The portable, durable, efficient bowl is easily cleaned, drops neatly in your pocket, and can be used in nearly any smoking context.

Now we’re ready to share this classic design so you can make the most of wherever you are with a quick smoke break. We’re raising funds to expand AC’s design into a modular smoking system, all based around his first piece, the AC Greebs Smoking Steel.

Machined from 304 stainless, the Smoking Steel turns bottles into efficient smoking devices. It travels easily, without the fear of broken glass. Its jetted airways create incredibly milky hits, while using a minimal amount of your precious herbs. 

The tapered shape seals airtight in most standard 2-liter and smaller bottles, yet it's easily removed. And because it's stainless, cleaning is a breeze. Just toss the Smoking Steel in a small container (we like film canisters, if you can find one) with some alcohol and salt, shake vigorously, and you're set to go. 

What We Need

When we started this project, our goal was to make something more effective than a socket melted through a bottle cap and more portable and durable than glass. We think the Smoking Steel is exactly that. 

Now, with your help, we can bring our larger vision to life. Your contributions will help us do two things.

First, you can help us fill an order at a scale that becomes cost-efficient. Turning these out by hand is great for friends and family, but we want to share with everyone. 

Second, you can help us prototype a line of accessories to expand on the functionality of the Smoking Steel. Our first planned accessory is a pipe base to allow for bottle and water-free use of the bowl.

What You Get

When you contribute, you can choose from our list of perks, including receiving one of the first Smoking Steels produced. We also have perks to beef up your wardrobe with an AC Greebs shirt and to share the joy of the Smoking Steel with friends. Most importantly, we can get your Smoking Steel to you in time to go under your Christmas trees. 

Donations can be made anonymously and perks will be shipped in a discreet box or envelope.

Everyone who contributes will also receive a coupon for 15% off a purchase from the AC Greebs online store when we launch in 2014. 


Early supporters can get our Early Bird perks, which are limited in number and will ship in time for the holidays. Bring smiles to your loved ones' faces by donating early. 

With the go-anywhere, indestructible, quick-cleaning AC Greebs Smoking Steel we can turn corner stores to head shops. And it will happen with your support!

Frequently Asked Questions

How do I use it?

The Smoking Steel bowl is made to be versatile and modular, and as such your imagination is really the only limitation. However, the most common approaches are the Gravity method and the Waterfall method. Here is some more insight into the Waterfall:


Why steel?

We use the same, high quality food grade stainless steel used every day by food and pharmaceutical makers. Stainless steel was developed not to leach any chemicals or corrode in even the harshest environments. It’s what hypodermic needles and most surgical tools are made of. Best of all, it is suited for high temperatures well beyond what a lighter flame can reach. The other main reasons we chose steel are these:

  • Steel will not shatter. Throw it in your backpack, drop it on the ground. Back over it with your car. Besides being food-safe and sanitary, you will not need to replace it.

  • The weight of the Steel creates an airtight seal when dropped into a standard sized bottle without needing to thread anything. Thread sizes can vary widely. The Smoking Steel skips that inconvenience with an exacted shape, diameter, and weight.


How hot does the piece get while in use?

In our experience and from feedback through our beta testers, you need to take about 6 or 7 Gravities back to back (and we mean rapid-fire back to back) in order to get the piece even warm enough to notice. If that is something you are repeatedly doing, we should hang out sometime.

Isn’t smoking out of a plastic bottle unhealthy?

PET is very stable at the temperatures the Smoking Steel is meant to operate at. The thermal mass of the bowl keeps heat from the direct flame and cherry from reaching temperatures high enough to cause PET to give off gas or melt. Any smoke that's cool enough to put in your lungs is not going to be anywhere close to the temperatures that would affect PET. There is no difference between inhaling air or smoke (at room temp) out of a bottle and inhaling water or some other beverage out of a PET bottle.

Some people have probably had experiences with PET where it smelled like chemicals- this is because they got the PET hot enough to melt or burn. Don't burn PET and there isn't a problem. The Greeb is specially engineered to keep the heat away from the PET as opposed to old school methods that make it easy to melt the bottle with your lighter.

That said, smoking anything isn't exactly healthy. If you have concerns about some trace amount of nanites or some other chemical goblins getting into your smoke you may want to think about another form of consumption.

Where are AC Greebs Products Manufactured?

The AC Greebs Smoking Steel is an American product manufactured in Richmond, Virginia. As compared to many “high tech” smoking devices that are marketed as healthier or higher quality but are often made from questionable parts or materials overseas, our factory floor is about five minutes away from our front door and for us, quality control is job one. 


Testimonials

Real feedback from real people. Some names have been changed for privacy.


"In Oregon we call them 'liters' 'waterfalls' and 'aqua lungs' for the most part. I've taken more of them than any other form of smoking since I learned about it in 1997. I absolutely love your product."  

- Johnny Green, TheWeedBlog.com


"The piece is clutch. This has to be the most effective, easy, simple, and cleanly designed head piece. No melted plastic, knife cutting, unnecessary tools. Literally drops in, air tight, easy to pull back out. I doubted this thing as a smoking gimmick but AC Greebs is the real deal."  - RZY


"The fact that this thing can be thrown in a pocket, and used virtually everywhere rivals only the 'bat' one-hitters or the classic J as a small smoking device. I throw it in my pocket with a bag, and off I go to a friend's place." - FZ


"The purists smoking with glass on glass connectors and all sorts of vaporizer gadgetry...may snicker at using a metal bowl, but this tool is effective and charming in a back-to-basic, retro-future sort of way." - Animal New York


"It's the main piece I use. It's great." - Everyday Smoker

Who We Are

We're a bunch of guys who went to graduate advertising school together. We were also in the same high school at the same time. Some of us even grew up on the same street. We're... Well, it's easier to read these than to prattle on:

Andrew Crowder is the hardest working man in machine business. His tolerances are high, his finishes smooth, and his Gcode poetry. When not designing or inventing new devices like the AC Greebs, you can find him atop his motorcycle or tending goal on the soccer field.

The most chilled out person in any room is undoubtedly Jamie Young. Always quick with an encouraging word and an easy smile, he’s the glue that keeps the AC Greebs apparatus alive. Jamie’s always thinking about the culture of Greebs and it’s his dreams that keep us moving forward.

Tyler Campbell Wriston, or Summer Pretty, is responsible for Art Direction and Branding at AC Greebs. He is the most tattooed member of the team, has instigated the most fights, and gives excellent hugs. He currently works at Mother in New York.

Always the man with the plan, Charles Merritt comes fully prepared to whip the team into shape and take action. With a resume steeped in media production, marketing and something called creative technology, he can arm wrestle almost any problem into submission with entrepreneurial spirit alone. And though his hair has migrated from pate to face over the years, he’s still the most ruggedly handsome guy in the room.

Sometimes teacher, sometimes student, Thomas Scott, now just plain Scott, originally joined the team as Jamie, Charles, and Tyler’s high school English teacher. Now he’s the driving force behind creating AC Greebs content, when he can get a break from collecting classic cars and mid-century modern furniture.

story:
After seeing lot of limitations with PPE/EDC, their huge costs and environmental wastage - we knew there was a much better way! 
 

Hence, we created KEYsistant - the first multi-function, anti-microbial tool. With the free carabiner, stylus and pullreel, its in fact a 12-in-1 or more! It looks like a Key; helpful like an Assistant;  resilient and resistant to germs as its made of pure solid brass.   

We believe you'll find it indispensable during the pandemic and beyond...

Stay Safe!
Frances 
 
 
Why us? Glad you asked 


Note: *Lifetime warranty, returns, refunds apply only on core metal KEYsistant not free promo accessories (split ring, carabiner, stylus tips, pull-reel) of the IGG campaign. 

KEYSistant makes it easy......

 




No more elbows, pens, tissue, or spraying before touching. Use it anywhere...



Hold handle bars in the bus or train; tear simple packing, flip switches! 

It includes  FREE carabiner, stylus tips, split ring & pull reel to reduce cross contamination. Never drop, lose or forget keys, ID card again. 


Bring your keys, ID card together. No clunky clutter. Attach it to the free rugged carabiner! 

Want to explore it in 360 degrees or in 3D/AR or VR? 

From the NY Times, FDA, scientists, environmentalists are raising the alarm on Covid19 wastage, infection from surfaces and how some PPE/EDC is causing  environmental harm.  

 

Millions of people use public places everyday, get infected from germs and spread them. 

It's  what its made of that makes the difference Vs. not how it looks or priced. 
Don't fall for  'lookalikes' made of cheap, ineffective materials that are colour coated. 

 

Brass is validated by the US EPA and Scientists for its oligodynamic properties and KEYsistant is independently tested. 
 

 

Spread the word. Stop the spread. Get  generous 20% cashback for every referral



Made by Professionals. Created from Experience. Validated by Experts. 

It took us 7 months of hard work to take it from research, 2D to 3D to prototypes, testing, revisions to production to get it ready for shipping!  


 

Made at an ISO-9001 certified, 20,000 Sqm specialist facility with 20 years experience led by an R&D team of metallurgy experts. 

Each KEYsistant is  moulded from pure solid brass, polished manually, inspected, and packed individually for the best quality. No short cuts. 
 

Independently certified by internationally accredited lab (compliant with FDA, ASTM, ISO, USP, DIN, JS) that specializes in testing metal quality, PPE, health & safety. 

 

Be informed with news you can use! 

https://paper.li/KEYsistant#/  > Click here!
 

About the Creators  

This is our 15th year! We are a female owned (yay girl power!) company.

We shipped hundreds and thousands of products to happy customers.  We design custom products for give-aways, marketing, events, CSR for corporates, users, start ups, theme parks, retailers and governments to make their brand memorable.    

Outside work, I am the mother of a curious 8-year old &  13-year old Egyptian Mau cat. 


Risks and challenges

Except 'force majeur', how we are mitigating potential risks and challenges:

-Product is ready to be shipped now!
-Core team has 120 years experience in design, production, engineering 
-Covered by our fair returns, refunds & replacement policies.
-Lifetime Warranty on core product i.e. KEYsistant. Note, it does not apply on optional/free accessories  i.e. split ring, carabiner, stylus tips and pull-reel, part of the IGG campaign. 
-Multiple shipping & production partners to avoid single point failures
-KEYsistant is lab tested, certified, compliant and customs cleared. 

Long-lasting 
When used & maintained as recommended, core brass by which KEYsistant is made of can last for hundreds of years. There is lot of archaeological evidence for this.

Reusability and recyclability
 We used recyclable brass. Even the cardboard packing is recyclable.  
Even after recycling, brass does not lose its intrinsic properties and less energy-intensive and yields smaller carbon footprint Vs. aluminium, iron, plastic or steel etc. 

Environmentally friendly factories
Made in ISO-9001 certified specialist metal facility as per European standards.

Sustainable Distribution
We ship via sea from factories so its less carbon footprint than via air. 
-Distribution to backers via road instead of air.
.........................................................................................................................................................

Credits: We acknowledge all sources cited; Flaticon and Freepik ; Ram, Sri, Seshu and agency partners Content HQ. All copyrights belong to their respective owners.

story:
Short Summary

Hello, My name is Kerry Morris and I am Stevens mom. Steven was born with TCS- Treacher-Collins Syndrome. Throughout his life- he has gone through many different surgeries- through Sick Childrens in Toronto as well as at UBC and Childrens Hospital in BC. He has suffered from sleep apnea- labored breathing- no overbite for chewing food as well as the personal affects of not looking the way he wants to look. With TCS-

Symptoms

  • Outer part of the ears are abnormal or almost completely missing

  • Hearing loss

  • Very small jaw (micrognathia)

  • Very large mouth

  • Defect in the lower eyelid (coloboma)

  • Scalp hair that reaches to the cheeks

  • Cleft palate

Signs and tests

The child usually will show normal intelligence. Examination of the infant may reveal a variety of problems, including:

  • Abnormal eye shape

  • Flat cheekbones

  • Clefts in the face

  • Small jaw

  • Low-set ears

  • Abnormally formed ears

  • Abnormal ear canal

  • Hearing loss

  • Defects in the eye (coloboma that extends into the lower lid)

  • Decreased eyelashes on the lower eyelid

What We Need & What You Get

What we are looking for is help in paying for the chin augmentation- as it is not covered as it is considered cosmetic surgery. Dr. Reichman the dental surgeon has suggested that if we can raise or come up with the money- he can do both surgeries at one time- which would make life alot easier for Steven. For many years- he has always talked to me about how he looks and what he wants to look like- and as his mother- i want to make that possible for him. But this is where help comes in from other people as I am on disability and my funds are limited- I need to raise $2800.00 to help him get his chin implant. By any help we get- Steven and I will be grateful for the rest of our lives.

The Impact

Steven is a great young man- and he has been with me since the day he was born- and his looks have never bothered me- i love him just the way he is- but this isnt about what mom wants- its about what Steven wants. I feel that if he finally can get this chin implant- he will feel more secure with who is as a man.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are not able to help- we are open to any other links or suggestions that may help us accomplish raising the funds for this surgery.

chins_up_for_steven@yahoo.com
story_txt:
Short Summary
Hello, My name is Kerry Morris and I am Stevens mom. Steven was born with TCS- Treacher-Collins Syndrome. Throughout his life- he has gone through many different surgeries- through Sick Childrens in Toronto as well as at UBC and Childrens Hospital in BC. He has suffered from sleep apnea- labored breathing- no overbite for chewing food as well as the personal affects of not looking the way he wants to look. With TCS-

Symptoms


Outer part of the ears are abnormal or almost completely missing


Hearing loss


Very small jaw (micrognathia)


Very large mouth


Defect in the lower eyelid (coloboma)


Scalp hair that reaches to the cheeks


Cleft palate




Signs and tests
The child usually will show normal intelligence. Examination of the infant may reveal a variety of problems, including:


Abnormal eye shape


Flat cheekbones


Clefts in the face


Small jaw


Low-set ears


Abnormally formed ears


Abnormal ear canal


Hearing loss


Defects in the eye (coloboma that extends into the lower lid)


Decreased eyelashes on the lower eyelid





What We Need & What You Get
What we are looking for is help in paying for the chin augmentation- as it is not covered as it is considered cosmetic surgery. Dr. Reichman the dental surgeon has suggested that if we can raise or come up with the money- he can do both surgeries at one time- which would make life alot easier for Steven. For many years- he has always talked to me about how he looks and what he wants to look like- and as his mother- i want to make that possible for him. But this is where help comes in from other people as I am on disability and my funds are limited- I need to raise $2800.00 to help him get his chin implant. By any help we get- Steven and I will be grateful for the rest of our lives.


The Impact
Steven is a great young man- and he has been with me since the day he was born- and his looks have never bothered me- i love him just the way he is- but this isnt about what mom wants- its about what Steven wants. I feel that if he finally can get this chin implant- he will feel more secure with who is as a man.


Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you are not able to help- we are open to any other links or suggestions that may help us accomplish raising the funds for this surgery.
chins_up_for_steven@yahoo.com

story:
Short Summary

We are simply tired of paying ridiculous amounts for common web services! And you should be too!

  • Justin is a programmer extraordinaire with 13 years’ experience in advanced coding and AI. He is completely “loonie” when it comes to his passion for coding and creating easy to use services for non-technical folk.
  • Guy in an entrepreneur with 25 years in the technical trenches. His entire focus is “loonie” .. who ever thought of web services for $1/month
  • We are approached every day for better, cheaper web services (web hosting, design, programming, monitoring and the list goes on. We finally decided to take the plunge and find a way to offer these services.
  • Bottom line... without the contributors our timeline for completion will be 5x longer, it is your generosity that will make this a reality and it is you who will benefit from our efforts.

Would you like the ability to have a website and hosting for $1/month? Would you like to have your computer network maintained for $1/month/computer? Do you have critical online services that you need monitored? Do you have a web service idea that you would like to see offered for $1/month?

What We Need & What You Get

Here it is folks:

This is a $10,000/project to launch. This pays for our programmer's time, our designer's time, basic marketing and hosting.

  • This will offer web template design/hosting for $1/month (assuming you have an existing domain name).
  • We have more $1/month project requests coming in everyday

If we don’t reach our goal for donations we will simply take a bit longer to make it happen. Either way the project will go forward. 
If we exceed our goal we will launch as many $1/month services as we possibly can with the funds!

The Impact

This is a game changer. There is no other service like it... anywhere!

  • $1/month for your own website, blog etc... need we say more?

COME ON WORLD!! THIS IS JUST THE START!
